replies.context: This is hypochlorous acid (part of bleach), not antibiotics.  It's not something that can just be evolved around like antibiotics.  It's one of the reasons hospitals have been moving to more bleach-based disinfection.

context:
photo op.  

far more efficient to send a few folks around with the 40 lbs you can carry on your back connected to a wand sprayer.  

Come on.  Ask obvious questions, "journalists."  Like, how would this device carry many pounds of disinfectant?

replies.context:
"far more efficient to send a few folks around with the 40 lbs you can carry on your back connected to a wand sprayer.  "

No, it's not.  We've done a lot of testing on that front.  We have the backpack sprayers to go with the drone, because the drone can't get near a wall.

The drone is an ag drone.  It can carry around 10 liters of fluid, and runs at around 12 miles per hour.  It goes over seats like nobody's business.  Humans don't move that fast, or we'd be using humans to do it instead.

10 liters of water is 10 kg or 22 lbs.   A human can carry at least twice the load on his/her back.

So how long does it take you to return your drone to its loading base, manually re-fuel it (and is that via human intervention? and if so how much labor is calculated in for that?), and then return to its route?  

what you've provided is hardly sufficient to counter my point.  please provide more data.

"A human can carry at least twice the load on his/her back."

Yes, we can.  The problem gets to be the speed of moving up and down stadium rows, and in and out of seats.  We also can't run for long periods of time at 12 MPH.

"So how long does it take you to return your drone to its loading base, manually re-fuel it (and is that via human intervention?"

That's part of our process - timing the refills of fluid and battery swaps so as to maximize efficiency.  There's a fair amount of math that goes into getting that right, and ideally the battery gets low near one of our staging points (in between sections).  Runners keep batteries and fluid going, and battery swaps take seconds.  Fluid refills take as long as you would expect to pour out 10 litres.

The labor is most certainly calculated into it.

"please provide more data."

That is a long, technical discussion, and not one that is particularly appropriate for short comments on a news article.  That drone is designed to fly in a pack of four in an outdoor environment, and to perform at about 3.5 hours to do 160 acres.  Stadiums are a bit slower, but not as much as you might think.  Beyond that, we'll just have to let our results speak for themselves.

also is the drone able to simultaneously move large trash to the aisles for disposal?

Is the ballpark merely doing this to demonstrate that they are committed to covid disinfecting?

"also is the drone able to simultaneously move large trash to the aisles for disposal?"

The spraying is done after the staff have gone through cleaning up trash, and very soiled surfaces.

replies.context:
One of the reason that large drones/common drones/ag drones have built-in no-fly-zone capabilities.

They place flight restrictions in the vicinity of stadiums during events.
Flight restrictions won’t stop a determined enemy, but some type of electronic protection that would ground drones would, I guess

There are a number of commercially available systems to do just that, ranging from jamming solutions to nets to interception drones to lasers that burn things out of the skies.

The payload is relatively limited, and if terrorists do start drones seriously one day, we'll see these systems start to be used more.
Counter measures will be needed certainly. Panic in a stadium would take a heavy toll.

The drone used in the video, by the way, has a built-in altitude limit that's much more aggressive than the limits imposed by the FAA. It wouldn't climb the steep wall on the outside of many stadiums.

To get it to climb to upper levels, you have to go up from the inside, as it won't get that high above ground on the outside.

replies.context: The cleaning is not limited to stadium seats.  That's just the part done by drones.  There are also indoor surfaces to clean, like concession stands, box seats, bathrooms, etc., where COVID-19 can persist significantly longer.
I agree. Cleaning is not worth the time. The issue is people too close together.
The issue is actually fear and ignorance of the people.. people to close together is an agenda to drive people apart, not trust in one another..

Well, I won't argue about the ignorance part.

The virus is expelled from the lungs, and gets into the surrounding air, so the closer you are to someone, the more likely you will be exposed to the virus if they have it.

This is known. It's not uncommon for numerous viruses to spread to people who are in close proximity, if they are airborne. Every country in the world recommends people avoid gathering in groups. Every country in the world has recommended this for other diseases during other pandemics.

Because it is so obvious that this helps that human beings have done this for various illnesses for literally thousands of years, even without knowing exactly what germs and viruses ARE. 

If you actually think that this situation is so unique that it must be some kind of conspiratorial agenda to drive people apart...please take a look at history. Or just sit down and think about this as what it is: something that exists regardless of any country's politics.
